action_space.name: Assessment and Collaborative Formulation
action_space.description: The therapist systematically gathers information to understand the patient's symptoms, problems, and underlying cognitive-behavioral processes, and collaborates with the patient to develop an individualized formulation guiding treatment.

goal.objective: To achieve a shared understanding of the patient's difficulties and develop a guiding framework for intervention.

success_levels.ideal: Therapist and patient collaboratively produce a comprehensive formulation that accurately connects cognitions, emotions, behaviors, and life context, guiding focused intervention.
success_levels.acceptable: A working formulation is established, covering key symptoms and basic cognitive-behavioral links, but may require further refinement.
success_levels.unsuccessful: No shared understanding is reached; the patient remains unclear about their difficulties or sees the formulation as irrelevant or confusing.

goal.reward_hint: Patient expresses understanding of the formulation; session discussions reference it as a roadmap for intervention.

states: Initial therapy sessions where background, symptoms, or difficulties are being explored.
When the patient's difficulties are unclear, complex, or treatment response is poor.
At transition points, relapses, or when new issues emerge and a revised formulation is necessary.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Patient Narrative and Symptom Description
micro_actions.description: Ask open-ended questions to prompt the patient to describe recent experiences, symptoms, and their emotional/behavioral impact in detail.
states: Early sessions when establishing reasons for seeking therapy.
When symptoms or presenting problems need clarification.

micro_actions.name: Administer Standardized Assessment Tools
micro_actions.description: Introduce and facilitate completion of validated questionnaires and symptom/rating scales to gather explicit data on mood, anxiety, and cognitive patterns.
states: Initial assessment phase.
When tracking symptom changes over time.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Map CBT Model
micro_actions.description: Use guided questioning and reflection to connect specific situations, thoughts, emotions, and behaviors, often using visual aids/worksheets, and invite patient input on their formulation.
states: After basic information is gathered.
When proposing a CBT-based explanation of difficulties.

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Clarify Dysfunctional Cognitions and Core Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Ask targeted questions (e.g., downward arrow technique) to uncover assumptions, rules, and core beliefs that may underlie presenting problems.
states: When unclear or persistent symptoms suggest deeper issues.
During formulation refinement.

micro_actions.name: Validate Patient Perspective and Invite Feedback
micro_actions.description: Summarize understanding, reflect back the patient's concerns, and explicitly ask for correction or confirmation to ensure accuracy and engagement.
states: Any time formulation or assessment is presented.
Whenever feedback can enrich shared understanding.

micro_actions.name: Review, Revise, and Summarize Formulation
micro_actions.description: Verbally and/or visually summarize the working hypothesis/formulation in the patient's language, check for understanding, and collaboratively agree on its accuracy or needed changes.
states: End of assessment or when shifting to intervention planning.
At key therapy transition points.

action_space.name: Therapeutic Alliance and Engagement Building
action_space.description: The therapist prioritizes developing a collaborative, empathic, and trusting therapeutic relationship to maximize patient motivation, engagement, and openness.

goal.objective: To foster an effective working alliance characterized by trust, collaboration, and patient engagement in the therapeutic process.

success_levels.ideal: The patient is actively engaged, feels understood and supported, and collaborates on treatment goals and strategies.
success_levels.acceptable: The patient is generally cooperative and attends sessions but may require ongoing encouragement to participate fully.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Therapeutic rapport is poor, patient is disengaged, distrustful, or resistant to treatment.

goal.reward_hint: Patient displays openness, asks questions, and collaborates willingly on interventions and homework.

states: Early stages of therapy with any patient.
When there is noticeable hesitance, skepticism, or disengagement.
After therapeutic ruptures, conflicts, or trust difficulties.
With patients where previous therapies have failed due to alliance issues.

micro_actions.name: Express Empathy and Validation
micro_actions.description: Use affirming, warm, and nonjudgmental language to acknowledge the patient's emotional experience and struggles.
states: Initial contact and throughout rapport building.
When the patient expresses distress or shame.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Agenda and Goal Setting
micro_actions.description: Ask for patient input on session structure and treatment targets, negotiate priorities, and confirm shared plans.
states: Session openings and when new issues arise.
Any time patient buy-in may be low.

micro_actions.name: Invite and Address Patient Feedback
micro_actions.description: Elicit reactions to therapist interventions, check for misunderstanding or discomfort, and openly discuss concerns or ruptures.
states: After new interventions; when resistance, withdrawal, or dissatisfaction appear.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Difficulties and Struggles
micro_actions.description: Use explicit statements to convey that setbacks, strong emotions, and therapy challenges are common and expected.
states: When the patient feels guilt, shame, or frustration.
During setbacks or low motivation.

micro_actions.name: Review and Reinforce Progress and Effort
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge any effort, positive change, or engagement, even if minimal; offer praise and reinforcement.
states: After the patient attempts homework, skills, or difficult disclosures.
Session closure or review points.

micro_actions.name: Address Ruptures or Misunderstandings Immediately
micro_actions.description: Recognize and bring up tension, conflict, or withdrawal, inviting repair and exploring causes in a non-defensive manner.
states: When alliance appears compromised.
Following critical incidents or missed sessions.

action_space.name: Psychoeducation and Socialization to CBT
action_space.description: Therapist provides education about the CBT model, symptom mechanisms, and the rationale for therapy to empower the patient and align expectations.

goal.objective: To increase patient understanding of their problems and the structure and rationale of CBT interventions.

success_levels.ideal: Patient can accurately describe the CBT model, identifies how thoughts/behaviors impact emotions, and is motivated to participate.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient shows basic understanding and buy-in, with some gaps or doubts.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is confused, misunderstands the model, or resists interventions.

goal.reward_hint: Patient is able to explain CBT principles and relate them to their experiences during session.

states: At the outset of therapy before engaging in techniques.
Recurrent confusion about therapy rationale or interventions.
When introducing new models (e.g., exposure, thought records, behavioral experiments).

micro_actions.name: Explain CBT Framework with Patient-Relevant Examples
micro_actions.description: Use concrete situations from the patient's life to illustrate the CBT model’s components (thoughts, emotions, behaviors, physical sensations).
states: Initial psychoeducation sessions.
When introducing new intervention techniques.

micro_actions.name: Provide Rationale for CBT Interventions
micro_actions.description: Offer brief, clear explanations for each proposed technique (e.g., 'We use thought records to uncover patterns in your thinking that affect how you feel').
states: Before using any new CBT tool or method.
If the patient resists homework or new skills.

micro_actions.name: Use Educational Materials and Visual Aids
micro_actions.description: Give handouts, diagrams, or demonstrations to clarify CBT concepts and encourage active patient engagement in learning.
states: When verbal explanations are insufficient or patient has learning/style needs.
At any point information retention is a concern.

micro_actions.name: Check Patient Understanding
micro_actions.description: Use teach-back, open questions, or short quizzes to assess the patient's grasp of CBT principles and correct misconceptions.
states: After psychoeducation delivery.
When the patient seems confused or skeptical.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Symptom Mechanisms
micro_actions.description: Use explicit statements that reframe symptoms as understandable reactions, reducing stigma and promoting engagement.
states: When patient expresses shame, misunderstanding, or stigma.
Early in therapy or during crises.

action_space.name: Goal and Agenda Setting
action_space.description: Therapist and patient collaborate to set specific, achievable treatment goals and jointly structure each session with an actionable agenda.

goal.objective: To focus therapy on clear, mutually agreed targets, ensuring efficient and purposeful sessions.

success_levels.ideal: Therapist and patient identify meaningful, specific goals and regularly set and complete clear agendas for each session.
success_levels.acceptable: General goals and session structures are agreed-upon and mostly followed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Sessions are unfocused, with no clear goals or agendas, leading to meandering or unproductive therapy.

goal.reward_hint: Session begins with explicit goal/agenda setting; end-of-session review confirms agenda progress.

states: Start of treatment to anchor therapy direction.
Start of each session to clarify focus.
When therapy becomes unfocused, or when new issues arise.
When motivation wanes or progress stalls.

micro_actions.name: Invite Patient Input on Session Agenda
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to specify priority issues or goals for the session, noting their suggestions explicitly.
states: Session opening.
Whenever session priorities are unclear.

micro_actions.name: Clarify and Operationalize Goals
micro_actions.description: Prompt the patient to state goals in concrete, observable, and measurable terms (e.g., 'What would success look like this week?').
states: Initial session or at start of new module/intervention.
When setting long-term and session-level targets.

micro_actions.name: Summarize and Confirm Agenda/Goals
micro_actions.description: Restate agreed-upon goals/agenda and confirm with patient understanding and buy-in.
states: Post agenda/goals negotiation.
Before proceeding with new content.

micro_actions.name: Review Agenda Progress Mid- and End-Session
micro_actions.description: Periodically check progress toward the agenda/goals and invite patient reflection or adjustments as needed.
states: Midway and end of session.
When sessions veer off course.

micro_actions.name: Address Obstacles to Goal Setting
micro_actions.description: Probe for barriers (internal or external) interfering with goal identification/achievement and collaboratively problem-solve solutions.
states: When patient struggles to generate goals or agenda items.
When progress stalls or avoidance arises.

action_space.name: Cognitive Intervention (Thought Identification and Restructuring)
action_space.description: Therapist guides the patient to identify, evaluate, and restructure automatic thoughts, maladaptive beliefs, and core schemas using Socratic questioning, cognitive restructuring, and related strategies.

goal.objective: To help the patient recognize and modify dysfunctional cognitions that drive distress and maladaptive behavior.

success_levels.ideal: Patient reliably identifies automatic thoughts, successfully challenges distortions, and adopts more adaptive perspectives.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient makes progress recognizing and questioning unhelpful thoughts, with occasional support needed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Little or no change in thinking patterns; patient clings to maladaptive cognitions or cannot apply restructuring techniques.

goal.reward_hint: Patient generates alternative, more balanced thoughts during or between sessions.

states: Presentation/logging of strong emotions, symptoms, or dysfunctional behavior.
Patient reports 'stuck' thinking or overt cognitive distortions.
In exposure to situations that evoke core beliefs or negative thoughts.
Whenever practical, to reinforce cognitive model skills.

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Label Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Ask targeted, situation-specific questions (e.g., 'What went through your mind when that happened?'), prompting the patient to articulate and record thoughts verbatim.
states: When discussing emotional reactions or behavioral events.
Throughout cognitive restructuring modules.

micro_actions.name: Identify and Categorize Cognitive Distortions
micro_actions.description: Guide the patient to spot and label thinking errors (e.g., catastrophizing, black-and-white thinking), using worksheets or direct Socratic questioning.
states: When dysfunctional thoughts emerge.
During review of thought records.

micro_actions.name: Challenge Unhelpful Thoughts via Socratic Questioning
micro_actions.description: Ask open, gently probing questions about the evidence for and against beliefs (e.g., 'What is the evidence for this thought? Against it?'), using patient examples.
states: Any time maladaptive cognitions are identified.
During cognitive interventions.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Generate Alternative Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Assist the patient in brainstorming and articulating more balanced/realistic perspectives, often writing or revising these together.
states: After challenging distortions.
When preparing coping cards or new responses.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Rating of Thought Belief Strength
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to rate conviction in old and new thoughts/beliefs (0-100%), tracking changes over time.
states: After cognitive exercises.
When monitoring progress in changing beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Probe for Core Beliefs and Schemas
micro_actions.description: Use downward arrow technique or recursive questioning to uncover more fundamental beliefs governing thoughts and behaviors.
states: When persistent patterns or emotional 'hot spots' remain.
During advanced restructuring phases.

action_space.name: Behavioral Experimentation and Exposure
action_space.description: Therapist collaboratively designs and implements behavioral experiments or exposure tasks with the patient to test beliefs, reduce avoidance, and promote adaptive learning.

goal.objective: To gather experiential evidence that challenges unhelpful beliefs and reduces avoidance behaviors.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes planned experiments or exposures, reflects on results, and modifies beliefs/behaviors adaptively.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient attempts behavioral tasks with partial completion or limited insight gained.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Experiments/exposures are avoided, incomplete, or ineffective in addressing target beliefs or behaviors.

goal.reward_hint: Patient completes experiment/exposure and discusses learning or belief change in subsequent session.

states: When safety behaviors, avoidance, or strongly held beliefs are identified.
After cognitive interventions highlight beliefs suitable for empirical testing.
In treatment of anxiety, OCD, depression, PTSD, phobia, eating and related disorders.
When cognitive work stalls or insight does not generalize to behavior.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Design Behavioral Experiments or Exposure Tasks
micro_actions.description: Jointly set up concrete, context-sensitive experiments targeting specific beliefs/behaviors (e.g., activity scheduling, ritual delay, exposure hierarchy step).
states: After identification of target beliefs or behaviors.
At planning phase for behavioral change.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Explicit Pre-experiment Predictions and Ratings
micro_actions.description: Prompt the patient to make and record detailed predictions about what will occur, including belief strength or anxiety levels before the experiment.
states: Immediately before experiment/exposure.
When using worksheets or diaries.

micro_actions.name: Detect and Challenge Safety Behaviors
micro_actions.description: Ask about and collaboratively plan to observe, drop, or test coping/safety behaviors that may prevent genuine learning during the experiment.
states: Planning phase and during experiment.
Review of past unsuccessful experiments.

micro_actions.name: Coach and Encourage During Experiment/Exposure
micro_actions.description: Provide real-time support, verbal encouragement, or troubleshooting to help the patient engage adaptively (e.g., bring attention back when avoidance arises).
states: During experiments or exposure exercises.
At moments of patient distress/discomfort.

micro_actions.name: Prompt Systematic Recording of Observations
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to document experiences, emotional responses, and outcomes during and after the experiment for review.
states: Throughout the experiment/exposure.
Immediately after experiment completion.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Structured Reflection and Debrief
micro_actions.description: Guide patient in reflecting on experiment outcomes vs. predictions, discussing implications for beliefs and possible generalization.
states: Post-experiment.
When drawing lessons or modifying future plans.

micro_actions.name: Iteratively Adapt Experiments Based on Results
micro_actions.description: Encourage review of outcomes and adjustment of subsequent experiments to address obstacles or refine learning.
states: After experiment cycles or setbacks.
As tolerance for exposure increases.

action_space.name: Skills Training and Coping Strategy Development
action_space.description: Therapist teaches, models, and practices specific coping skills with the patient (e.g., problem solving, relaxation, emotion regulation, assertiveness, communication) to address deficits and support adaptive functioning.

goal.objective: To build and reinforce practical coping abilities supporting cognitive and behavioral change.

success_levels.ideal: Patient demonstrates acquisition and appropriate use of taught skills in-session and in daily life.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient is learning and attempts skills with varied success; ongoing support is needed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Skills are not acquired or practiced, and coping deficits persist.

goal.reward_hint: Patient uses skills outside of therapy and reports improved coping with targeted issues.

states: Patient exhibits maladaptive coping, skill deficits, or functional impairment.
Emotional or behavioral goals require practical intervention (e.g., assertiveness for social anxiety, relaxation for physiological arousal).
Relapse prevention phases needing reinforcement of self-efficacy and self-management.

micro_actions.name: Teach, Model, and Demonstrate Coping Skills
micro_actions.description: Provide step-by-step instruction, modeling (e.g., role-play, demonstration), and rationale for each skill (e.g., relaxation, assertiveness, problem-solving).
states: When introducing new skills.
During practice and troubleshooting defective coping.

micro_actions.name: Guide Collaborative Skill Practice and Rehearsal
micro_actions.description: Lead exercises, role-plays, or in-session rehearsals; support patient participation and give immediate corrective feedback.
states: In-session and during homework assignment phases.
When skill acquisition requires active demonstration.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Use of Worksheets, Diaries, or Logs to Track Skill Usage
micro_actions.description: Prompt completion of worksheets tracking mastery, emotion ratings, and events related to skill use; review with patient for feedback.
states: During skill-building and monitoring phases.
For progress tracking.

micro_actions.name: Provide Feedback, Reinforcement, and Problem-Solving
micro_actions.description: Praise successful use of skills, troubleshoot difficulties or barriers, and encourage persistence in applying skills outside therapy.
states: After skill use (in or between sessions).
When patient faces setbacks.

micro_actions.name: Encourage Generalization and Application of Skills
micro_actions.description: Prompt reflection on where, when, and how newly acquired skills can be transferred to real-life challenges.
states: During or after skills training.
Throughout relapse prevention planning.

action_space.name: Homework Assignment and Review
action_space.description: Therapist assigns, reviews, and collaboratively troubleshoots homework tasks (thought records, experiments, activity scheduling, skills practice) to generalize learning and promote between-session progress.

goal.objective: To reinforce and extend therapeutic learning outside of sessions and to identify and address barriers to change.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes homework, gains new insights or makes changes, and homework is reviewed constructively in-session.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient completes most homework with some challenges; review is used to problem-solve obstacles.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Homework is not assigned, completed, or reviewed; learning does not generalize, and engagement is limited.

goal.reward_hint: Timely homework completion; discussion of homework is regular and leads to new therapeutic targets.

states: Following sopistication of a skill or intervention requiring consolidation.
At session end as a bridge to next session.
When between-session learning or practice will enhance therapy gains.
When lack of progress signals the need to address barriers to homework.

micro_actions.name: Assign Clear, Concrete Homework with Rationale
micro_actions.description: Explain the purpose, steps, and expected outcomes for homework tasks; record them explicitly in writing.
states: End of session and after intervention introduction.
When new skills/exercises need extra practice.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Customization and Troubleshooting of Homework
micro_actions.description: Invite patient feedback, address anticipated and actual barriers, break down assignments to smaller steps as needed.
states: At assignment of homework.
When homework adherence has failed.

micro_actions.name: Review Homework Progress and Experiences
micro_actions.description: Ask open questions about homework completion, challenges, insights, and review content in-session for reflection or problem solving.
states: Start or end of session, post-assignment.
When progress needs to be monitored.

micro_actions.name: Adjust and Reassign Homework Based on Experience
micro_actions.description: Modify tasks or provide alternatives when original homework is not feasible, ensuring a 'win' and continued engagement.
states: After reviewing incomplete or overly difficult homework.
After major life changes affecting previous plans.

micro_actions.name: Encourage Use of Reminders, Checklists, and External Aids
micro_actions.description: Suggest practical supports (e.g., phone alerts, visual notes, worksheet binders) to promote adherence and recall between sessions.
states: For patients struggling with organization or memory.
When homework is frequently forgotten or skipped.

micro_actions.name: Praise Effort and Reflect on Learning from Homework
micro_actions.description: Offer recognition for attempts and engagement, encourage reflection on what was learned regardless of outcome.
states: After homework review.
During periods of partial completion or setbacks.

action_space.name: Reflection, Consolidation, and Progress Monitoring
action_space.description: Therapist facilitates structured reflection on interventions, explores implications for beliefs and behavior, and monitors progress toward treatment goals.

goal.objective: To enable the patient to extract learning, consolidate changes, and maintain awareness of progress and setbacks.

success_levels.ideal: Patient articulates insights from interventions, recognizes areas of growth or continuing challenge, and tracks progress.
success_levels.acceptable: Reflection and monitoring occur but are more therapist-led or superficial.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient does not reflect on sessions or recognize changes, leading to stagnation or premature dropout.

goal.reward_hint: Patient reports specific learning, identifies successful changes, and adapts goals as progress is reviewed.

states: After completion of major interventions or at natural breaks (e.g., post-experiment).
When evaluating overall therapy progress (midpoint, discharge planning).
After setbacks, plateaus, or relapse.

micro_actions.name: Prompt Structured Reflection on Intervention Outcomes
micro_actions.description: Ask targeted questions (e.g., 'What did you learn from this experience?', 'How did the result compare to your prediction?') to facilitate reflection on specific exercises or experiments.
states: Immediately after behavioral/cognitive interventions.
At review points in therapy.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Progress Tracking with Ratings and Logs
micro_actions.description: Support patient in regularly rating beliefs, symptoms, mood, and activity, and recording changes in worksheets or diaries.
states: During routine monitoring.
After interventions or at planned review points.

micro_actions.name: Summarize and Consolidate Gains
micro_actions.description: Verbally and/or in writing, highlight achievements, changes, or key insights, and invite patient to acknowledge progress.
states: Session closures, progress review, or before transitions.
When positive changes are evident.

micro_actions.name: Identify Remaining Challenges and Setbacks
micro_actions.description: Invite discussion of ongoing difficulties, failures, or relapses, normalize these experiences, and collaboratively set new targets.
states: After setbacks, plateaus, or incomplete progress.
During relapse prevention or transition planning.

micro_actions.name: Revise Formulation or Goals Based on Reflection
micro_actions.description: Update working hypotheses, goals, or therapy plans in collaboration with the patient based on new insight or progress.
states: After reflection reveals change in focus needs.
When planning next phase of therapy.

action_space.name: Termination, Relapse Prevention, and Follow-up Planning
action_space.description: Therapist prepares the patient for the end of therapy by planning for maintenance of gains, relapse prevention, and promoting patient autonomy.

goal.objective: To sustain treatment outcomes, minimize risk of relapse, and encourage continued self-management beyond therapy.

success_levels.ideal: Patient independently uses CBT techniques, has a relapse prevention plan, and responds adaptively to setbacks.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient recognizes warning signs and seeks help or returns to CBT tools as needed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is unprepared for therapy ending, quickly relapses, or does not use learned skills.

goal.reward_hint: Patient articulates a clear plan for self-management; booster sessions or follow-up shows maintained gains.

states: When therapy goals are substantially achieved.
Toward planned discharge or transition to maintenance/booster phase.
When discussing anticipated high-risk situations or setbacks.

micro_actions.name: Review and Celebrate Therapy Gains and Skill Acquisition
micro_actions.description: Summarize key achievements, highlight learned skills, and invite patient reflection on progress and changes.
states: Near discharge or therapy completion.
During booster/final sessions.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Relapse Prevention Planning
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively brainstorm and document early warning signs, high-risk situations, and specific action plans for maintaining progress.
states: Final phase of active therapy.
When preparing for return to usual life after therapy.

micro_actions.name: Teach and Reinforce Self-Monitoring Skills
micro_actions.description: Prompt regular rating of mood, beliefs, and coping efforts; support use of logs, reminders, and relapse management worksheets.
states: In maintenance phase.
When self-management needs strengthening.

micro_actions.name: Plan for Continued Practice and Booster Sessions
micro_actions.description: Schedule, discuss need for, and encourage use of booster sessions or check-ins as part of follow-up planning.
states: Final sessions or relapse prevention planning.
When patient expresses concern about future setbacks.

micro_actions.name: Encourage Patient Autonomy and Ownership
micro_actions.description: Explicitly ask patient to articulate their own strategies for coping and maintaining gains, reinforce autonomous use of CBT tools.
states: Immediately prior to termination.
When evaluating readiness for independent self-management.

conversation_states.Description: The patient's current level of belief in target, alternative, and core cognitions. This matters because the level of conviction informs the need for cognitive restructuring, experiment targeting, and progress tracking.
Current intensity and type of emotion (e.g., anxiety, distress, sadness, anger). This matters for understanding the patient’s moment-to-moment experience and tailoring interventions or pacing.
Presence, type, and frequency of safety behaviors and avoidance strategies. Essential for targeting exposures, behavioral experiments, and evaluating progress.
Strength and quality of collaboration, trust, and engagement between patient and therapist. Crucial for session openness, treatment adherence, and outcome.
Current motivation level and willingness to engage with cognitive or behavioral change, experiments, and homework. This informs intervention selection and session pacing.
Activation and type of cognitive distortions or processing biases (e.g., catastrophizing, selective attention, discounting positives) present in patient thinking.
Level of patient awareness regarding their own thoughts, feelings, physiological reactions, and behavioral tendencies within and outside the session.
Whether patient operates predominantly with analytical (intellectual) or experiential (emotional) conviction, and flexibility vs. rigidity in thinking style.
Where the patient is within the cycle: planning, experiencing, observing, or reflecting on behavioral experiments. Influences session structure and intervention timing.
Patient's level of engagement with session activities and adherence to homework, exposure tasks, and behavioral experiments.
Intensity and type of physiological symptoms (e.g., palpitations, sweating, dizziness) associated with emotional states; relevant for panic, anxiety, and somatic concerns.
The extent to which new insights, behaviors, or belief changes are applied beyond the therapy context to real-world situations.
The presence and impact of comorbid symptoms (depression, social anxiety, chronic pain, substance abuse) and their effect on session goals or CBT intervention.
Level and quality of support or reinforcement from social/environmental sources (e.g., family, friends, workplace), and their effect on therapy progress.
Any practical, psychological, or situational barriers preventing progress, engagement, or completion of homework and tasks (e.g., motivation, cognitive deficits, avoidance, logistical issues).
Current patient appraisal of self-worth, safety, autonomy, competence, and perception of the external world, indicating which cognitive triad domain is most activated.
Observed or reported shifts in mood or emotion within the session, particularly in response to experiments, interventions, or insight development.
Patient’s openness and confidence to try new behavioral experiments or exposures after discussing results or encountering setbacks.
The degree to which the patient is able to reconsider beliefs, assimilate new evidence, and shift behavior as a result of therapeutic experience.

nodes.description: The individual undergoing cognitive behavioral therapy; all tracked long-term dimensions are grouped under this root node.
History of presenting problems, diagnostic profile, comorbid conditions, symptom onset and course.
Significant life events, developmental antecedents, trauma, formative experiences, family/social/cultural influences.
Therapist’s working model; cognitive formulations, individualized models, and evolution of case conceptualization over time.
Enduring core beliefs, schemas (about self/other/world), conditional/intermediate assumptions, rules for living.
Record of key automatic thoughts, recurring cognitive distortions, patterns of thinking, typical content and triggers.
Typical biases (catastrophic thinking, personalization, etc.), attributional style, persistent cognitive errors, and their evolution.
Patterns of emotional reactions (types, intensity, triggers), emotional vocabulary, chronic emotional difficulties, and mood tracking.
Behavioral activation/avoidance patterns, completed behavioral experiments, outcomes, safety behaviors, rituals.
Types and history of safety behaviors, avoidance strategies, rescue behaviors, coping efforts (both adaptive and maladaptive).
Patterns in physiological arousal (e.g., panic symptoms), sleep, health behaviors, functioning (social, occupational, academic).
Interventions used, homework adherence and outcomes, skill development (thought records, CBT tools), and mastery/self-efficacy ratings.
Progress on goals, symptom/challenge trajectories, relapse prevention status, learning generalization, and setbacks/relapses.
History of assigned homework, activities scheduled/completed, associated barriers, and grading of mastery/pleasure.
Social network, relationship history/dynamics, support resources, interpersonal beliefs and behavior, alliance with therapist.
Medication history, biological/medical risk factors, side effect/adherence history.
Metacognitive and process-level beliefs, confidence/conviction strength, responses to uncertainty and thought-related beliefs.
History of self-injury, suicidality, addiction, relapse warning signs, crisis management and protective/risk factors.
Cultural background, social roles, environmental or contextual influences on cognition/behavior and therapy engagement.
Quality of alliance, collaboration, rupture/repair history, boundary management, therapist-patient process notes.
Personal values, goal history, action plans, motivation and readiness to change, achievements, and barriers.
Patient’s understanding of the CBT model, learning curve, generalization of skills, insight into their own difficulties, response to psychoeducation.

cautions.description: Therapist strictly implements CBT procedures without adapting to patient context.
cautions.risk: May result in ineffective treatment, loss of rapport, and failure to address patient needs.

cautions.description: Therapist ignores collaborative, empathic relationship with patient.
cautions.risk: Breakdown of trust, reduced engagement, and poor therapy outcomes.

cautions.description: Therapist allows or encourages safety behaviors during behavioral experiments or exposures.
cautions.risk: Undermines cognitive change and maintains anxiety or avoidance patterns.

cautions.negative_action: Force or rush patients into overwhelming experiments
cautions.description: Therapist pushes patients into experiments that they do not understand, accept, or wish to perform.
cautions.risk: Increases distress, reduces engagement, and risks patient demoralization.

cautions.description: Therapist shares private information or acts outside accepted professional roles.
cautions.risk: Damages trust, risks legal/ethical consequences, and harms the therapeutic relationship.

cautions.description: Therapist fails to account for medical safety or doesn't obtain medical clearance when relevant.
cautions.risk: Potential for harm or exacerbation of medical conditions.

cautions.description: Therapist treats failed behavioral experiments as signs of treatment failure rather than opportunities for learning.
cautions.risk: Demoralization and decreased patient motivation.

cautions.description: Therapist forces patients into exposures they are not prepared for.
cautions.risk: Can increase avoidance, distress, or dropout.

cautions.negative_action: Argue about physical vs. psychological symptoms
cautions.description: Therapist debates the nature of symptoms prematurely.
cautions.risk: Can damage rapport and increase resistance.

cautions.description: Therapist questions or confronts deeply held beliefs without patient readiness or alliance.
cautions.risk: Threatens the therapeutic relationship and reduces treatment credibility.

cautions.negative_action: Overgeneralize or use ambiguous experimental designs
cautions.description: Therapist uses poorly controlled or overly broad experiments.
cautions.risk: Confounds learning and risks invalid conclusions.

cautions.description: Therapist ignores the patient's background when interpreting or designing interventions.
cautions.risk: Risks misinterpretation and ineffective or offensive intervention.

cautions.negative_action: Coerce or surprise patients with traumatic exposures
cautions.description: Therapist gives either excessive warning or no warning before exposing patients to distressing situations.
cautions.risk: Can traumatize or alienate the patient, or reduce treatment engagement.

cautions.description: Therapist does not assess or adjust for substance use, depression, or physical illness.
cautions.risk: May result in inappropriate or unsafe interventions.

cautions.description: Therapist gives tasks without specificity, rehearsal, or attention to barriers.
cautions.risk: Limits learning, increases risk of non-compliance and discouragement.

cautions.description: Therapist fails to monitor or prioritize suicidal thoughts or hopelessness.
cautions.risk: Endangers patient safety.

cautions.negative_action: Ignore patient autonomy in treatment planning
cautions.description: Therapist does not elicit patient input or control.
cautions.risk: Reduces engagement, efficacy, and empowerment.

cautions.description: Therapist dismisses, minimizes, or ignores emotional pain, resistance, or reluctance.
cautions.risk: Risks disengagement, loss of trust, and perpetuates symptoms.

cautions.negative_action: Push for rapid change without preparation
cautions.description: Therapist attempts to accelerate progress prematurely, ignoring readiness and obstacles.
cautions.risk: Risks overwhelming or demoralizing the patient.

cautions.description: Therapist plans experiments that are either too difficult or too trivial.
cautions.risk: Can obstruct progress and demotivate or overwhelm the patient.

cautions.description: Therapist encourages behaviors that maintain anxiety or compulsions.
cautions.risk: Prevents progress and perpetuates problem behaviors.

cautions.description: Therapist lectures or dictates rather than working collaboratively.
cautions.risk: Damages alliance and undermines engagement.

cautions.description: Therapist fails to discuss, adapt, or support homework tasks.
cautions.risk: Limits learning and skill acquisition.

cautions.negative_action: Prescribe or recommend medication outside expertise
cautions.description: Therapist advises on medication without relevant qualifications.
cautions.risk: Risks patient safety and is potentially unethical or illegal.

cautions.negative_action: Proceed despite contraindications (e.g., acute mania, psychosis)
cautions.description: Therapist conducts cognitive therapy when patient is clinically unstable, or with inappropriate method selection.
cautions.risk: May worsen symptoms, exacerbate risk, or delay appropriate intervention.
